factoid: The plate was not quite clean to the man.
The man pointed to a spot and flung the plate away.
Tíkhon caught the plate and handed it to a footman.
The little princess was not unwell.
The little princess had an overpowering fear of the prince.
The little princess heard that the prince was in a bad humor.
The little princess decided not to appear because of her fear.
The little princess said to Mademoiselle Bourienne: 'I am afraid for the baby.'
The little princess said to Mademoiselle Bourienne: 'Heaven knows what a fright might do.'
At Bald Hills the little princess lived in constant fear.
The little princess had a sense of antipathy toward the old prince.
The little princess did not realize her antipathy because fear was stronger.
The prince reciprocated the little princess's antipathy.
The prince's contempt for the little princess overpowered his antipathy.
The little princess grew accustomed to life at Bald Hills.
The little princess took a special fancy to Mademoiselle Bourienne.
The little princess spent whole days with Mademoiselle Bourienne.
The little princess asked Mademoiselle Bourienne to sleep in her room.
The little princess often talked with Mademoiselle Bourienne about the old prince.
The little princess often criticized the old prince.
Mademoiselle Bourienne remarked: 'So we are to have visitors, mon prince?'
Mademoiselle Bourienne unfolded her white napkin with rosy fingers.
Mademoiselle Bourienne said: 'His Excellency Prince Vasíli Kurágin and his son, I understand?'
The prince said: 'Hm!—his excellency is a puppy. I got him his appointment in the service.'
The prince said: 'Why his son is coming I don’t understand.'
The prince said: 'Perhaps Princess Elizabeth and Princess Mary know.'
The prince said: 'I don’t want him.'
The prince looked at his blushing daughter.
The prince asked: 'Are you unwell today?'
The prince asked: 'Eh? Afraid of the minister as that idiot Alpátych called him this morning?'
Mademoiselle Bourienne replied: 'No, mon père.'
Mademoiselle Bourienne had been unsuccessful in her choice of a subject.
Mademoiselle Bourienne did not stop talking.
Mademoiselle Bourienne chattered about the conservatories.
Mademoiselle Bourienne chattered about the beauty of a flower that had just opened.
After the soup the prince became more genial.
After dinner the prince went to see his daughter-in-law.
The little princess was sitting at a small table.
The little princess was chattering with Másha, her maid.
The little princess grew pale on seeing her father-in-law.
The little princess was much altered.
The little princess was now plain rather than pretty.
The little princess's cheeks had sunk.
The little princess's lip was drawn up.
The little princess's eyes were drawn down.
The little princess said: 'Yes, I feel a kind of oppression.'
The little princess said: 'Do you want anything?'
The little princess said: 'No, merci, mon père.'
The little princess said: 'Well, all right, all right.'
The prince left the room.
The prince went to the waiting room where Alpátych stood with a bowed head.
The prince asked: 'Has the snow been shoveled back?'
Alpátych answered: 'Yes, your excellency. Forgive me for heaven’s sake. It was only my stupidity.'
The prince interrupted: 'All right, all right.'
The prince laughed in his unnatural way.
The prince stretched out his hand for Alpátych to kiss.
The prince proceeded to his study.
Prince Vasíli arrived that evening.
Prince Vasíli was met in the avenue by coachmen and footmen.
Coachmen and footmen dragged Prince Vasíli's sleighs up to a lodge over the road laden with snow.
Prince Vasíli and Anatole had separate rooms assigned to them.
Anatole had taken off his overcoat.
Anatole sat with arms akimbo before a table.
Anatole smiled and fixed his large and handsome eyes.
Anatole regarded his whole life as a continual round of amusement.
Anatole looked on the visit to a churlish old man and a rich and ugly heiress in the same way.
Anatole thought that the visit might turn out very well and amusingly.
Anatole thought: 'And why not marry her if she really has so much money? That never does any harm.'
Anatole shaved and scented himself with care and elegance.
Anatole's handsome head was held high.
Anatole entered his father's room with good-humored and victorious air.
Prince Vasíli's two valets were busy dressing him.
Prince Vasíli looked around with much animation.
Prince Vasíli nodded to his son.
Anatole asked: 'I say, Father, joking apart, is she very hideous?'
Anatole continued the conversation about the subject that had often been mentioned during the journey.
Anatole said: 'Enough! What nonsense! Above all, try to be respectful and cautious with the old prince.'
